TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   Fatigue x One Week.  Transferred to CCU for hypoxic respiratory
   distress
   24 Hour Events:
   - Spiked temp 101
   - atrial ectopy with PACs on tele, magnesium repleted
   - was unresponsive in setting of afib with rvr, then became acutely
   agitated after rectal thermometer, called son and he calmed patient
   down, also called psych given acute paranoia and history of holocaust
   survivor.
   - psych reccs: stop ativan and mirtazipine, check tox screen, b12,
   folate. haldol 1mg po for acute agitation if needed.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia given fever and
   opacities on chest x ray.  The patient may also have a component of CHF
   given elevated BNP, elevated JVP and, mild peripheral edema as well as
   symptomatic improvement after diuresis on the medicine floor.  PE was
   also in the differnetial, although less likely since the pt was
   theraputic on coumadin.  Atrial tachycardia/fibrilation exacerbated
   hypoxia last night.  Baseline anemia and restrictive lung may make
   reserve poor contributing to profound hypoxia as well
   -- Follow up chest x ray read
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime for pneumonia requiring ICU
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals
   -- stop diltiazem per EP
   -- standing nebs Q 4 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- f/u urine legionella
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- continue lasix 20 mg IV
   -- echo to assess for CHF
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  However, reverted back to atrial fibrillation versus
   multifocal atrial tachycardia last night in the setting of fever and
   hypoxia.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP stop diltiazem
   -- continue dofetillide
   -- EKG 2 hrs after dose to measure QTc
   -- Clarify coumadin dose (coumadin 5 mg Q 5 days, 2.5 mg Q 2 days?)
   # altered mental status: patient tachycardic to 150s and unresponsive
   initially with somnolence.  Pt recently had taken home mirtazapine and
   ativan and is hard of hearing which may have contributed.  But
   tachycardic to 150s with decreasing O2 saturation worrisome for hypoxia
   causing AMS.  Pt underwent unsuccessful carotid massage and had rectal
   temp, then became agitated and violent, paranoid that he was being
   molested.  Redirected with talking with his son and avoided chemical
   restraints.
   -- appreciate psych recs to D/C ativan and mirtazepine
   -- f/u tox screen
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor, atenolol
   .
   # Hypertension:
   --continue atenolol and nifedipine
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:
   -- holding mirtazepine, ativan per psych
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet if not looking like he will need intubation
   this am
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .
   #ACCESS: PIV
   # Communication:
   [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (wife) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12544**]
   [**Name (NI) 12545**] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (son) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12546**]
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 RESTRICTIVE LUNG DISEASE (INCLUDING NEUROMUSCULAR, CHEST WALL)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 76**])

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with hypoxic respiratory distress and atrial fibrillation. The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.5°F (38.6°C)
* Heart rate: 108 bpm
* Blood pressure: 99/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 89%
* Blood oxygen level: 34 mmHg

The patient has a history of pneumonia, which is likely causing his hypoxic respiratory distress. He also has a component of congestive heart failure (CHF) given his elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level and mild peripheral edema. The patient's anemia and restrictive lung disease may also contribute to his poor respiratory reserve and profound hypoxia.

The patient's mental status has been altered, and he has been experiencing agitation, paranoia, and hallucinations. He has a history of depression and insomnia, and he was taking home medications for these conditions, which may have contributed to his altered mental status.

The patient has a number of medical conditions, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, chronic sinusitis, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), hyperlipidemia, depression, and insomnia. He is taking a number of medications, including aspirin, atenolol, lipitor, and flonase.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress and pneumonia increase his risk of developing respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease increase his risk of developing cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and potential hypoxia increase his risk of developing neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.
5. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of developing secondary infections.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, I recommend the following plan:

1. Continue to provide supportive care, including mechanical ventilation and vasopressors as needed.
2. Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and consider adding coverage for atypical pathogens.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider sedation or anesthesia if necessary.
4. Consider echocardiography to assess for CHF and pulmonary hypertension.
5. Consider stress testing or other cardiac testing to assess the patient's cardiac function.
6. Consider neuroimaging to assess for potential neurological complications.
7. Monitor the patient's laboratory results, including complete blood counts, electrolyte levels, and liver function tests.
8. Consider adding prophylactic antibiotics for secondary infections.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcome.

   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia given fever and
   opacities on chest x ray.  The patient may also have a component of CHF
   given elevated BNP, elevated JVP and, mild peripheral edema as well as
   symptomatic improvement after diuresis on the medicine floor.  PE was
   also in the differnetial, although less likely since the pt was
   theraputic on coumadin.  Atrial tachycardia/fibrilation exacerbated
   hypoxia last night.  Baseline anemia and restrictive lung may make
   reserve poor contributing to profound hypoxia as well
   -- Follow up chest x ray read
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime for pneumonia requiring ICU
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals
   -- control heart rate with dilt gtt
 convert to PO
   -- standing nebs Q 4 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- f/u urine legionella
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- continue lasix 20 mg IV
   -- echo to assess for CHF
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  However, reverted back to atrial fibrillation versus
   multifocal atrial tachycardia last night in the setting of fever and
   hypoxia.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- consult EP re: stopping dilt gtt and converting to PO (30 mg Q 6 hr)
   along with dofetilide
   -- continue dofetillide
   -- EKG 2 hrs after dose to measure QTc
   -- Clarify coumadin dose (coumadin 5 mg Q 5 days, 2.5 mg Q 2 days?)
   # altered mental status: patient tachycardic to 150s and unresponsive
   initially with somnolence.  Pt recently had taken home mirtazapine and
   ativan and is hard of hearing which may have contributed.  But
   tachycardic to 150s with decreasing O2 saturation worrisome for hypoxia
   causing AMS.  Pt underwent unsuccessful carotid massage and had rectal
   temp, then became agitated and violent, paranoid that he was being
   molested.  Redirected with talking with his son and avoided chemical
   restraints.
   -- appreciate psych recs to D/C ativan and mirtazepine
   -- f/u tox screen
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor, atenolol
   .
   # Hypertension:
   --continue atenolol and nifedipine
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:
   -- holding mirtazepine, ativan per psych
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet if not looking like he will need intubation
   this am
   .

   pain - tylenol

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient, a 75-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease, was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress and altered mental status. He has a history of fatigue, pneumonia, and coronary artery disease, which may contribute to his respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complex, with multiple comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension, chronic sinusitis, OSA, hyperlipidemia, depression/insomnia, and FEN/GI. He is currently receiving treatment for pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying restrictive lung disease, pneumonia, and atrial fibrillation. Close monitoring of his oxygen saturation and respiratory status is crucial to prevent further deterioration.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias. Close monitoring of his cardiac enzymes and ECG is necessary to detect any changes.
3. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of developing sepsis. Early recognition and treatment of sepsis are essential to prevent further complications.
4. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure may lead to acute kidney injury. Close monitoring of his renal function and urine output is necessary to detect any changes.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as ileus, nausea, and vomiting. Close monitoring of his gastrointestinal status is necessary to prevent further complications.
6. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of developing secondary infections. Close monitoring of his temperature and white blood cell count is necessary to detect any changes.
7. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure may lead to hemodynamic instability, including hypotension and tachycardia. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and heart rate is necessary to detect any changes.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status and hypoxia may lead to neurological complications such as seizures, brain edema, or cerebral vasospasm. Close monitoring of his neurological status is necessary to detect any changes.

In conclusion, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and treatment to prevent further complications. The potential medical complications listed above highlight the importance of early recognition and treatment to prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and other comorbidities. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress and altered mental status.

The patient's vital signs are concerning, with a fever of 101.5°F (38.6°C), tachycardia, and hypoxia. His respiratory status is also concerning, with severe kyphoscoliosis, increased work of breathing, and decreased breath sounds on both bases.

The patient's laboratory results are also concerning, with an elevated BNP, elevated JVP, and mild peripheral edema, suggesting possible congestive heart failure. His troponin-T levels are negative, but his CK and CKMB levels are elevated, suggesting possible cardiac injury.

The patient's mental status is also concerning, with a history of altered mental status, including somnolence, agitation, and paranoia. He has a history of depression and insomnia, and is currently being treated with mirtazapine and ativan, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.

The patient's medications are numerous and complex, including anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents, and cardiovascular medications. He is also receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and diuretics.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's severe kyphoscoliosis and hypoxia make him at high risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and congestive heart failure make him at high risk for cardiac complications, including cardiac arrest and cardiogenic shock.
3. Infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and history of depression and insomnia make him at high risk for neurological complications, including seizures and stroke.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient's anticoagulant therapy and history of bleeding complications make him at high risk for bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities and potential complications. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications, and to improve his respiratory and cardiovascular status.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia given fever and
   opacities on chest x ray.  The patient may also have a component of CHF
   given elevated BNP, elevated JVP and, mild peripheral edema as well as
   symptomatic improvement after diuresis on the medicine floor.  PE was
   also in the differnetial, although less likely since the pt was
   theraputic on coumadin.  Atrial tachycardia/fibrilation exacerbated
   hypoxia last night.  Baseline anemia and restrictive lung may make
   reserve poor contributing to profound hypoxia as well
   -- Follow up chest x ray read
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime for pneumonia requiring ICU
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals
   -- stop diltiazem per EP
   -- standing nebs Q 4 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- f/u urine legionella
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- continue lasix 20 mg IV
   -- echo to assess for CHF
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  However, reverted back to atrial fibrillation versus
   multifocal atrial tachycardia last night in the setting of fever and
   hypoxia.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP stop diltiazem
   -- continue dofetillide
   -- EKG 2 hrs after dose to measure QTc
   -- Clarify coumadin dose (coumadin 5 mg Q 5 days, 2.5 mg Q 2 days?)
   # altered mental status: patient tachycardic to 150s and unresponsive
   initially with somnolence.  Pt recently had taken home mirtazapine and
   ativan and is hard of hearing which may have contributed.  But
   tachycardic to 150s with decreasing O2 saturation worrisome for hypoxia
   causing AMS.  Pt underwent unsuccessful carotid massage and had rectal
   temp, then became agitated and violent, paranoid that he was being
   molested.  Redirected with talking with his son and avoided chemical
   restraints.
   -- appreciate psych recs to D/C ativan and mirtazepine
   -- f/u tox screen
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor, atenolol
   .
   # Hypertension:
   --continue atenolol and nifedipine
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:
   -- holding mirtazepine, ativan per psych
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet if not looking like he will need intubation
   this am
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and chronic conditions such as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic sinusitis. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress and was found to have pneumonia, likely caused by pneumonia given the presence of fever and opacities on chest x-ray.

The patient's physical examination revealed mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, mild pulmonary hypertension, and severe kyphoscoliosis. He had increased work of breathing, expiratory wheezes, and decreased breath sounds on both bases. His vital signs were stable, with a heart rate of 73 bpm, blood pressure of 95/48 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

Laboratory results showed anemia, elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP), and mild peripheral edema. The patient's cardiac enzymes were negative, and his troponin-T levels were <0.01 ng/mL.

The patient's conditions and potential medical complications are:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Distress: The patient's hypoxia is likely caused by pneumonia, and he may also have a component of congestive heart failure (CHF) given his elevated BNP and JVP. The patient may require mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to improve his oxygenation.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and his recent episode was likely exacerbated by his hypoxia. He is anticoagulated with coumadin, and his CHADS II score is 3. He may require further anticoagulation and rate control measures.
3. CHF: The patient's BNP levels are elevated, and his JVP is slightly above the clavicle, suggesting mild CHF. He may require diuresis and vasodilators to manage his symptoms.
4. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which is likely caused by a bacterial infection. He may require antibiotics and respiratory support to manage his infection.
5. Restrictive Lung Disease: The patient has restrictive lung disease, which may be contributing to his hypoxia. He may require bronchodilators and oxygen therapy to improve his lung function.
6. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He may require further management of his coronary artery disease, including aspirin and statins.
7. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which may be contributing to his hypoxia. He may require further management of his hypertension, including antihypertensive medications.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's atrial fibrillation and CHF may lead to cardiac arrest, which may require cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia may lead to sepsis, which may require antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Pneumothorax: The patient's restrictive lung disease and pneumonia may lead to pneumothorax, which may require chest tube placement and drainage.
5. ARDS: The patient's hypoxia and pneumonia may lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which may require mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue vanc and cefpipime for pneumonia
2. Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals
3. Stop diltiazem per EP
4. Standing nebs Q 4 hr plus PRN
5. High flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
6. F/u urine legionella
7. F/u sputum and blood cultures
8. Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
9. Tylenol PRN
10. Continue lasix 20 mg IV
11. Echo to assess for CHF
12. Per EP stop diltiazem
13. Continue dofetillide
14. EKG 2 hrs after dose to measure QTc
15. Clarify coumadin dose
16. Appreciate psych recs to D/C ativan and mirtazepine
17. F/u tox screen
18. Try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
19. Continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor, atenolol
20. Continue flonase
21. Resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
22. Continue atorvastatin
23. Hold mirtazepine, ativan per psych
24. Cardiac healthy diet if not looking like he will need intubation this am
25. DVT - Coumadin
26. Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
27. Pain - tylenol
28. PIV
29. Communication: ICU consent signed

   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia with  a possible
   component of CHF and poor baseline lung reserve.
   # Pneumonia: O2 saturations stable, but not yet improving on high flow
   mask.
   -- Follow up chest x ray read from this am
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**3-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**3-19**])
   -- standing nebs Q 6 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  Had an episode of atrial fibrillation versus multifocal
   atrial tachycardia the night of admission to the unit in the setting of
   fever and hypoxia.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- continue dofetillide (have completed 6 doses with no prolonged QT)
   -- Continue coumadin 5 mg q day
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- D/C ativan
   -- continue mirtazepine (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation

   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor
   .
   # Hypertension:
   --continue nifedipine
   -- holding atenolol as above
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:
   -- holding ativan per psych
   -- continue mirtazepine
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .

   pain - tylenol
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and chronic sinusitis. He was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 73 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 95/48 mmHg. He has a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 96%. His chest x-ray is pending, but his echo shows mild to moderate mitral regurgitation and mild regional systolic dysfunction.

The patient is receiving treatment for his pneumonia, including vancomycin and cefipime, and is being monitored for any signs of worsening respiratory failure. He is also being treated for his atrial fibrillation with dofetillide and is being anticoagulated with coumadin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he is at risk for worsening respiratory failure due to his pneumonia and underlying lung disease.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease, which increases his risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient has pneumonia and is at risk for developing other infections, such as urinary tract infections or sepsis.
4. Bleeding: The patient is being anticoagulated with coumadin, which increases his risk for bleeding complications.
5. Hyperkalemia: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may increase his risk for cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
6. Hypoxia: The patient's oxygen saturation is stable, but he is at risk for developing hypoxia due to his pneumonia and underlying lung disease.
7. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be due to his underlying medical conditions, but he is at risk for developing delirium due to his age, medications, and underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for pneumonia with vancomycin and cefipime.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
3. Continue treatment for atrial fibrillation with dofetillide and anticoagulation with coumadin.
4. Monitor the patient's potassium level and consider adjusting his medications if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and consider increasing his oxygen flow if necessary.
6. Consider starting a stress ulcer prophylaxis to reduce the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Monitor the patient's mental status and consider adjusting his medications if necessary to reduce the risk of delirium.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a chief complaint of fatigue, who was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and chronic sinusitis.

The patient's 24-hour events include:

* The patient's electrocardiogram (EKG) showed mild to moderate mitral regurgitation (MR) and mild regional systolic dysfunction.
* The patient's echocardiogram (ECHO) showed mild pulmonary hypertension.
* The patient's blood pressure was 95/48 mmHg, and his heart rate was 73 beats per minute (bpm).
* The patient's respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute (bpm), and his oxygen saturation was 96%.
* The patient was placed on BiPAP with subsequent improvement in his respiratory status.
* The patient's laboratory results showed:
	+ White blood cell count (WBC): 9.1-11.4 K/uL
	+ Hemoglobin (Hb): 12.1-13.1 g/dL
	+ Platelet count (Plt): 134-150 K/uL
	+ Creatinine (Cr): 1.1-1.2 mg/dL
	+ Troponin-T: <0.01 ng/mL
	+ Glucose: 106-119 mg/dL
	+ Lactic acid: 1.4 mmol/L
* The patient's chest X-ray is pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Hypoxic respiratory distress: likely due to pneumonia with a possible component of CHF and poor baseline lung reserve.
* Pneumonia: O2 saturations are stable, but not yet improving on high-flow mask.
* Atrial fibrillation: the patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide.
* Altered mental status: likely due to fever and tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.
* Coronary artery disease: the patient has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
* Hypertension: the patient has a history of hypertension and is taking nifedipine.
* Chronic sinusitis: the patient has a history of chronic sinusitis and is taking flonase.
* OSA: the patient has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and is being treated with BiPAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: the patient's hypoxic respiratory distress can progress to respiratory failure, which can lead to intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: the patient's atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease can lead to cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or heart failure.
* Infection: the patient's pneumonia can progress to sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
* Gastrointestinal complications: the patient's altered mental status and increased benzodiazepine dose can lead to gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and constipation.
* Hyperglycemia: the patient's high blood glucose levels can lead to hyperglycemia, which can increase the risk of complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
* Hypotension: the patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue vanc and cefipime for pneumonia
* Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals
* Continue BiPAP for OSA
* Continue mirtazepine for depression/insomnia
* Continue aspirin and lipitor for coronary artery disease
* Continue nifedipine for hypertension
* Continue flonase for chronic sinusitis
* Continue atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia
* Continue coumadin for DVT prophylaxis
* Continue senna and docusate for bowel regimen
* Continue tylenol for pain

Summary:

The patient, a 75-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress, pneumonia, and atrial fibrillation. He has a history of coronary artery disease, chronic sinusitis, and depression. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 85 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is receiving bipap support and has been converted to normal sinus rhythm with dofetillide. His laboratory results show anemia, leukocytosis, and elevated lactate levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's pneumonia and restrictive lung disease increase his risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his oxygen saturation and respiratory rate is essential.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease put him at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and elevated lactate levels increase his risk of sepsis. Close monitoring of his vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect early signs of sepsis.
4. Kidney Injury: The patient's oliguria/anuria and elevated creatinine levels suggest kidney injury. Close monitoring of his urine output and kidney function is essential to detect early signs of kidney injury.
5. Bloodstream Infection: The patient's central line and Foley catheter increase his risk of bloodstream infection. Close monitoring of his blood cultures and line infections is essential to detect early signs of bloodstream infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue bipap support and monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and respiratory rate closely.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and blood pressure closely, and adjust his medications as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's laboratory results, including his white blood cell count, lactate levels, and kidney function, and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.
4. Consider adding antibiotics to cover potential infections, such as MRSA and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
5. Consider transferring the patient to a step-down unit or a cardiac care unit if his condition stabilizes.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia with poor
   baseline lung reserve due to kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung.
   # Pneumonia: O2 saturations stable, but not yet improving on high flow
   mask.
   -- Follow up chest x ray read [**2159-4-24**]
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**4-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**4-19**])
   -- standing nebs Q 6 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   -- pt requesting PT to relieve back pain with message from scoliosis
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  Had an episode of atrial fibrillation versus multifocal
   atrial tachycardia the night of admission to the unit in the setting of
   fever and hypoxia.  Had another episode of a fib with RVR last night
   that was unresponsive to lopressor, but was rate controlled with
   diltiazem.  This afternoon the patient was noted to be in junctional
   rhythm again so diltiazem stopped. CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated
   with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- continue dofetillide
   -- holding diltiazem due to junctional rhythm in the 80s, will
   re-evaluate if pt has a fib with RVR again
   -- holding nifedipine due to metabolism interaction with diltiazem
   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart at 2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- holding nifedipine as above, will consider captopril for
   hypertension
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Pt made low urine last night.  Improved after IV
   bolus.  Was also started on maintenance fluids overnight.  Pt not
   taking in good PO due to desaturations without the facemask
   -- continue to bolus PRN for low urine output
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- D/C ativan
   -- continue mirtazepine (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych)
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilie which prolongs QT (although
   swtudies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.
   -- continue mirtazepine
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   -- discourage nasal lavage until respiratory status improves
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress and pneumonia. He has a history of kyphoscoliosis, which is contributing to his poor lung reserve. The patient's respiratory status has been unstable, requiring bipap and high flow nasal canula. He has also had episodes of atrial fibrillation, which has been managed with medication. The patient's urine output has been low, and he has required IV boluses to help with hydration. He has also had altered mental status, which is likely related to his fever, tachycardia, and increased benzodiazepine dose.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he is at risk for further decline, which could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia is not yet fully treated, and he is at risk for further complications, such as sepsis or respiratory failure.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is not well-controlled, and he is at risk for further episodes, which could lead to cardiac complications.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is not well-controlled, and he is at risk for further complications, such as cardiac damage or stroke.
5. Low urine output: The patient's low urine output is a concern, and he may be at risk for further complications, such as kidney damage or electrolyte imbalances.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and he may be at risk for further complications, such as delirium or cognitive decline.
7. Depression/insomnia: The patient's depression and insomnia are not well-managed, and he may be at risk for further complications, such as suicidal thoughts or decreased quality of life.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pneumonia with antibiotics and monitor for signs of improvement or deterioration.
3. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with medication and monitor for signs of further episodes.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's urine output and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's depression and insomnia and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent further complications.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia with poor
   baseline lung reserve due to kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung.
   # Pneumonia: O2 saturations stable, but not yet improving on high flow
   mask.
   -- Follow up chest x ray read from this am
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**3-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**3-19**])
   -- standing nebs Q 6 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after
   dofetillide.  Had an episode of atrial fibrillation versus multifocal
   atrial tachycardia the night of admission to the unit in the setting of
   fever and hypoxia.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- continue dofetillide (have completed 6 doses with no prolonged QT)
   -- Continue coumadin 5 mg q day
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- D/C ativan
   -- continue mirtazepine (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor
   .
   # Hypertension:
   --continue nifedipine
   -- holding atenolol as above
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   -- resume BiPAP when hypoxia resolves
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:
   -- holding ativan per psych
   -- continue mirtazepine
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress. He has a history of kyphoscoliosis, restrictive lung disease, and chronic sinusitis. He developed atrial fibrillation on the night of admission and was converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide administration. He also has oliguria/anuria, respiratory failure, and acute kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's oxygen saturation has not improved despite high-flow nasal canula, and his chest X-ray shows pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. He may require further antibiotic treatment and consideration of intubation.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure or stroke. He is already anticoagulated with coumadin, but his CHADS II score is 3, which may indicate a higher risk of stroke.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's restrictive lung disease and kyphoscoliosis may lead to further respiratory failure, which could worsen his oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Oliguria/Anuria: The patient's oliguria/anuria may indicate acute kidney injury, which could worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated, which may indicate hyperglycemia. He may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent complications.
6. Infection: The patient's pneumonia and oliguria/anuria may indicate a systemic infection, which could lead to further complications and worsen his overall condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotic treatment for pneumonia.
2. Consider further cardiac evaluation and treatment for atrial fibrillation.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider intubation if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's oliguria/anuria and consider further treatment for acute kidney injury.
5. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and consider further treatment for hyperglycemia.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment for infection.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and kyphoscoliosis, who presented with 5 days of fatigue and developed hypoxic respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on high-flow nasal canula and bipap mask, with O2 saturations stable but not yet improving. Chest X-ray shows pleural effusions, improved pulmonary edema, and unchanged consolidation.
* Cardiac: The patient is in sinus rhythm, but has a history of atrial fibrillation, and is anticoagulated with Coumadin. He is on dofetillide and has had episodes of atrial fibrillation and junctional rhythm.
* Renal: The patient has low urine output, which improved after an IV bolus, and is receiving maintenance fluids. He is also receiving diuretics.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, likely due to fever, tachycardia, and increased benzodiazepine dose. He is receiving mirtazapine and has had episodes of agitation.
* Infectious: The patient has pneumonia, with O2 saturations stable but not yet improving. He has had episodes of hypoxia and is receiving antibiotics.
* Other: The patient has chronic sinusitis, hyperlipidemia, and is on anticoagulation therapy for DVT prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress and pneumonia increase his risk of respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and recent episodes of atrial fibrillation and junctional rhythm increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's low urine output and potential for further decline in renal function increase his risk of renal failure.
* Infection: The patient's pneumonia and altered mental status increase his risk of infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and potential for further bleeding complications increase his risk of bleeding.
* Pulmonary edema: The patient's kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung disease increase his risk of pulmonary edema.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy
* Monitoring O2 saturations and adjusting therapy as needed
* Monitoring cardiac rhythm and adjusting therapy as needed
* Monitoring renal function and adjusting therapy as needed
* Continuing mirtazapine and considering low-dose haldol for anxiety
* Continuing dietary recommendations and nutrition consult
* Continuing prophylactic measures for DVT and stress ulcer prevention

The patient's family should be educated on his condition, treatment plan, and potential complications, and should be involved in his care and decision-making process.

   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart when <2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- Hold nifedipine as above
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Pt made low urine last night.  Improved after IV
   bolus.  Was also started on maintenance fluids overnight.  Pt not
   taking in good PO due to desaturations without the facemask
   -- continue to bolus PRN for low urine output
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- small doses of ativan PRN panic attacks
   -- continue mirtazepine HS plus PRN (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych) and use only if needed
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilide which prolongs QT (although
   studies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.

   .

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient, a 75-year-old man with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease, was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. He has a history of restrictive lung disease, kyphoscoliosis, and chronic sinusitis. The patient is currently on various medications, including vanc, cefipime, doxycycline, and diltiazem. He is experiencing oliguria/anuria, atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he requires high-flow nasal canula and bipap for oxygenation. He also has altered mental status, likely due to fever, tachycardia, and increased benzodiazepine dose.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is tenuous, and he requires high-flow nasal canula and bipap for oxygenation. There is a risk of further respiratory decline, which could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a high fever and is on antibiotics, which increases the risk of sepsis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his current medication regimen may not be adequately controlling his arrhythmias.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications.
5. Oliguria/anuria: The patient's urine output is decreased, which may indicate kidney dysfunction or failure.
6. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to various factors, including fever, tachycardia, and increased benzodiazepine dose. There is a risk of further decline in mental status, which could lead to delirium or coma.
7. Infection: The patient has a high fever and is on antibiotics, which increases the risk of infection.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status and chest X-ray suggest the possibility of pneumonia.
9. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is on medications that may increase the risk of cardiac complications.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's diet is cardiac-healthy, but there is a risk of nutritional deficiencies due to his decreased appetite and malabsorption.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, blood pressure, and cardiac rhythm.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as necessary to control his arrhythmias and hypertension.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to cover atypical bacteria if the patient's respiratory status does not improve.
4. Monitor the patient's urine output and consider adding diuretics if necessary.
5. Continue to provide nutrition and hydration support, and consider adding supplements if necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent further decline.
7. Consider adding prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent cardiac complications.

 OLIGURIA/ANURIA

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  O2 saturations tenuous but stable.
   Likely from pneumonia with poor baseline lung reserve due to
   kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung. Anxiety leading to tachypnea and
   with poor tidal volumes likely contributing.
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**5-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**5-19**])
   -- standing nebs Q 6 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Obtain VBG
   -- Low threshold for ABG and intubation
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   -- Requesting Chest PT per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 712**]
   -- pt requesting PT to relieve back pain with message from scoliosis
   -- Treat panic attacks with small doses of ativan (0.25mg)
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Underlying mechanism for RVR is most likely
   hypoxia as O2 sats tightly correlate with tachycardia. Patient
   converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide.  Had an episode of
   atrial fibrillation versus multifocal atrial tachycardia the night of
   admission to the unit in the setting of fever and hypoxia.  Had another
   episode of a fib with RVR last night that was unresponsive to
   lopressor, but was rate controlled with diltiazem.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt
   anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- will discuss with EP re discontinuing dofetillide as may not be
   working effectively as an antiarrythmic
   -- Diltiazem 30mg PO Q6H standing for now
   -- STOP nifedipine now that using diltiazem
   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart when <2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- Hold nifedipine as above
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Pt made low urine last night.  Improved after IV
   bolus.  Was also started on maintenance fluids overnight.  Pt not
   taking in good PO due to desaturations without the facemask
   -- continue to bolus PRN for low urine output
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- small doses of ativan PRN panic attacks
   -- continue mirtazepine HS plus PRN (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych) and use only if needed
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilide which prolongs QT (although
   studies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.
   -- continue mirtazepine
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   -- discourage nasal lavage until respiratory status improves
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   --- Continue BiPAP PRN
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following potential medical complications should be monitored and managed:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure should be monitored closely, and the patient should be considered for intubation if his oxygen saturation drops below 90%.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation should be managed with antiarrhythmic medications, and the patient should be considered for cardioversion if his atrial fibrillation persists.

5. Chronic sinusitis: The patient's chronic sinusitis should be managed with antibiotics and nasal decongestants, and the patient should be considered for hospitalization if his sinusitis persists.

Summary:

The patient is a 57-inch tall, 54.8 kg individual admitted to the ICU with fatigue for one week, who was subsequently transferred to the CCU for hypoxic respiratory distress. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure of 97/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 92%. The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient has a history of oliguria/anuria, restrictive lung disease, and respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to the underlying restrictive lung disease and the patient's current respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation (AF) may lead to cardiac complications such as embolism, stroke, or heart failure.
3. Infection: The patient's oliguria/anuria and respiratory failure may increase the risk of infection, particularly urinary tract infections.
4. Fluid imbalance: The patient's fluid balance is slightly negative, which may lead to dehydration or fluid overload.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels, particularly potassium, sodium, and magnesium, are slightly abnormal, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.
6. Renal complications: The patient's oliguria/anuria may lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's restrictive lung disease and respiratory failure may lead to malnutrition and decreased caloric intake.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and respiratory failure may increase the risk of pressure ulcers.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of VAP.
10. Stress ulcer: The patient's respiratory failure and underlying medical conditions may increase the risk of stress ulcer bleeding.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to monitor their vital signs closely, manage their respiratory and cardiac status, and prevent infections, fluid imbalance, and electrolyte imbalance. Additionally, the patient's nutritional needs should be assessed and addressed to prevent malnutrition, and measures should be taken to prevent pressure ulcers and stress ulcer bleeding.

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  Likely from pneumonia with poor
   baseline lung reserve due to kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung. O2
   saturations stable, but not yet improving on high flow mask.
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**5-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**5-19**])
   -- standing nebs Q 6 hr plus PRN
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Low threshold for repeat ABG and intubation if necessary
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   -- Starting Chest PT per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 712**]
   -- pt requesting PT to relieve back pain with message from scoliosis
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Underlying mechanism for RVR is most likely
   hypoxia. Patient converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide.
   Had an episode of atrial fibrillation versus multifocal atrial
   tachycardia the night of admission to the unit in the setting of fever
   and hypoxia.  Had another episode of a fib with RVR last night that was
   unresponsive to lopressor, but was rate controlled with diltiazem.
   This afternoon the patient was noted to be in junctional rhythm again
   so diltiazem stopped. CHADS II is 3.  Pt anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- will discuss with EP re discontinuing dofetillide as is not
   effectively working as antiarrythmic
   -- holding diltiazem due to junctional rhythm in the 80s except PRN,
   will re-evaluate if pt has a fib with RVR again
   -- continuing nifedipine for now
   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart at 2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- continue nifedipine as above
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Pt made low urine last night.  Improved after IV
   bolus.  Was also started on maintenance fluids overnight.  Pt not
   taking in good PO due to desaturations without the facemask
   -- continue to bolus PRN for low urine output
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- D/C ativan
   -- continue mirtazepine HS plus PRN (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych)
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilide which prolongs QT (although
   swtudies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.
   -- continue mirtazepine
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, lipitor
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   -- discourage nasal lavage until respiratory status improves
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   --- Continue BiPAP PRN
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .
   #ACCESS: PIV
   # Communication:
   [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (wife) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12544**]
   [**Name (NI) 12545**] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (son) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12546**]

   Nutrition: cardiac healthy

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and developed hypoxic respiratory distress. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for management of respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, and oliguria/anuria.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on high-flow nasal cannula and bipap mask, with an oxygen saturation of 92%. The patient has a restrictive lung disease, including neuromuscular and chest wall components, which is contributing to the respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is likely caused by hypoxia. The patient was converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetilide, but had an episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) last night, which was unresponsive to lopressor but was rate-controlled with diltiazem. The patient is anticoagulated with coumadin.
* Renal: The patient has oliguria/anuria, with a low urine output. The patient received an IV bolus and maintenance fluids overnight, and the urine output improved.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, which is likely caused by fever and tachycardia, as well as increased benzodiazepine dose. The patient is taking mirtazapine and trazodone, and the team is considering using low-dose haloperidol for anxiety.
* Other: The patient has coronary artery disease, chronic sinusitis, obstructive sleep apnea, hyperlipidemia, and a history of CABG.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen, leading to RVR, ventricular tachycardia, or ventricular fibrillation.
* Renal failure: The patient's oliguria/anuria can worsen, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status can worsen, leading to delirium, agitation, or seizures.
* Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and oliguria/anuria can increase the risk of infection, including pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or bloodstream infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation with coumadin can increase the risk of bleeding, including gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial bleeding, or hematuria.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the team should continue to monitor the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, renal, and neurological status closely and adjust treatment accordingly. The team should also consider ordering additional tests, such as a head computed tomography (CT) scan or a pulmonary artery catheterization, to further evaluate the patient's condition.

Chief Complaint: Fatigue x One Week.  Transferred to CCU for hypoxic
   respiratory distress
   24 Hour Events:
   [**4-26**]
   - continued home lactobacillus for constipation
   - written for PRN lorazepam
   - continued gentle hydration
   - nifedipine stopped; standing diltiazem written and up-titrated to
   60mg PO Q6H
   - VBG with rising pCO2; patient placed back on BiPAP at this time
   - Pt occasionally received dilt 10mg IV x 1 for RVR in 130s-140s

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  O2 saturations tenuous but stable.
   Likely from pneumonia with poor baseline lung reserve due to
   kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung. Anxiety leading to tachypnea and
   with poor tidal volumes likely contributing.
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**6-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**6-19**])
   -- continue nebs Q 6 hr PRN (changed to PRN given is not using this)
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Daily VBG
   -- Low threshold for ABG and intubation
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   -- Trial of gentle diuresis with Lasix 10mg IV ONCE and monitor O2
   status as may have a component of pulmonary edema
   -- pt requesting PT to relieve back pain with message from scoliosis
   -- Treat panic attacks with small doses of ativan (0.25mg) PRN
   -- Formal pulm consult with discussions re MICU transfer as patient
   primary problem seems pulmonary
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Underlying mechanism for RVR is most likely
   hypoxia as O2 sats tightly correlate with tachycardia. Patient
   converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide.  Had an episode of
   atrial fibrillation versus multifocal atrial tachycardia the night of
   admission to the unit in the setting of fever and hypoxia.  Had another
   episode of a fib with RVR last night that was unresponsive to
   lopressor, but was rate controlled with diltiazem.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt
   anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- will discuss with EP re discontinuing dofetillide as may not be
   working effectively as an antiarrythmic
   -- Diltiazem 60mg PO Q6H standing for now with 10mg IV PRN RVR
   -- STOP nifedipine now that using diltiazem
   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart when <2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- Hold nifedipine as above
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Improved.
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- small doses of ativan PRN panic attacks
   -- continue mirtazepine HS plus PRN (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych) and use only if needed
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilide which prolongs QT (although
   studies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.
   -- continue mirtazepine
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, Lipitor
   -- Rate control with dilt and treating underlying hypoxia and infection
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   -- discourage nasal lavage until respiratory status improves
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   --- Continue BiPAP PRN
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and kyphoscoliosis who was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory distress. He has been treated with vanc, cefipime, doxycycline, and nebs for pneumonia. His oxygen saturation is tenuous but stable, and he is on high-flow nasal canula and bipap for respiratory support. He has also been treated for atrial fibrillation with dofetillide and diltiazem.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is tenuous but stable, and he is on high-flow nasal canula and bipap for respiratory support. There is a risk of further deterioration of his respiratory status, which could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has been treated with antibiotics for pneumonia, but there is a risk of treatment failure or development of resistant bacteria.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and there is a risk of further episodes or development of atrial flutter.
4. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension, and there is a risk of further elevation of his blood pressure, which could lead to complications such as heart failure or stroke.
5. Low urine output: The patient has been experiencing low urine output, which could be a sign of dehydration or kidney dysfunction.
6. Altered mental status: The patient has been experiencing altered mental status, which could be a sign of infection, medication side effects, or other underlying medical conditions.
7. Depression/insomnia: The patient has been experiencing depression and insomnia, which could be a sign of underlying mental health conditions or medication side effects.
8. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, and there is a risk of further cardiac complications such as heart failure or myocardial infarction.

 PNEUMONIA, [**Hospital 2293**] HOSPITAL ACQUIRED (NON-VAP)
 OLIGURIA/ANURIA

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Mr. [**Name14 (STitle) 12541**] is a 75 YOM with paroxysmal atrial fibrilation and
   coronary artery disease who presented with 5 days of fatigue and
   developed hypoxic respiratory distress.
   .
   # Hypoxic Respiratory Distress:  O2 saturations tenuous but stable.
   Likely from pneumonia with poor baseline lung reserve due to
   kyphoscoliosis and restrictive lung. Anxiety leading to tachypnea and
   with poor tidal volumes likely contributing.
   -- Continue vanc, cefpipime (D # [**6-19**])
   -- Continue doxycycline to cover atypicals (D # [**6-19**])
   -- continue nebs Q 6 hr PRN (changed to PRN given is not using this)
   -- high flow nasal canula versus non-rebreather for sats > 93%
   -- bipap PRN for comfort for decreased O2 sats
   -- f/u sputum and blood cultures
   -- Daily VBG
   -- Low threshold for ABG and intubation
   -- tylenol PRN
   -- IV bolus to help hydrate during infection (and pt not taking good
   PO)
   -- Trial of gentle diuresis with Lasix 10mg IV ONCE and monitor O2
   status as may have a component of pulmonary edema
   -- pt requesting PT to relieve back pain with message from scoliosis
   -- Treat panic attacks with small doses of ativan (0.25mg) PRN
   -- Formal pulm consult with discussions re MICU transfer as patient
   primary problem seems pulmonary
   .
   # Atrial fibrilation: Underlying mechanism for RVR is most likely
   hypoxia as O2 sats tightly correlate with tachycardia. Patient
   converted to normal sinus rhythm after dofetillide.  Had an episode of
   atrial fibrillation versus multifocal atrial tachycardia the night of
   admission to the unit in the setting of fever and hypoxia.  Had another
   episode of a fib with RVR last night that was unresponsive to
   lopressor, but was rate controlled with diltiazem.  CHADS II is 3.  Pt
   anticoagulated with coumadin.
   -- per EP hold atenolol, will consider restaring or not at discharge
   -- will discuss with EP re discontinuing dofetillide as may not be
   working effectively as an antiarrythmic
   -- Diltiazem 60mg PO Q6H standing for now with 10mg IV PRN RVR
   -- STOP nifedipine now that using diltiazem
   -- holding Coumadin for now (supratheraputic) will restart when <2.5 mg
   -- f/u with EP regarding long term management for a fib
   .
   # Hypertension:
   -- Hold nifedipine as above
   -- holding atenolol as above
   # Low urine output:  Improved.
   .
   # altered mental status: Likely occurred in the setting of fever and
   tachycardia along with increased benzodiazepine dose.  .
   -- appreciate psych recs
   -- small doses of ativan PRN panic attacks
   -- continue mirtazepine HS plus PRN (pt did ok with this)
   -- will try low dose haldol 1 mg PO if needed for acute agitation
   .
   # Depression/insomnia:  Pt complained of insomnia last night and
   requested increased mirtazepine.  Received trazodone which left him
   groggy this am.  Family concerned about treating his anxiety, but team
   weary of using benzodiazepine given his tenuous respiratory status and
   multiple risk factors for delirium.
   -- prefer to hold ativan (recommended by psych) and use only if needed
   -- per psych may consider 0.25 mg haldol for anxiety, will weigh the
   cost/benefits given pt on dofetilide which prolongs QT (although
   studies show haldol prolongs QT less than other antipsychotics.
   -- continue mirtazepine
   # Coronary artery disease:  Status post CABG and [**Name Prefix (Prefixes) **] [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] 2.  ST
   depressions on EKG (stable, but worsened with tachycardia to 150s).  No
   active chest pain.  Cardiac enzymes negative.
   -- continue aspirin 81 mg, Lipitor
   -- Rate control with dilt and treating underlying hypoxia and infection
   .
   # Chronic sinusitis:
   -- continue flonase
   -- discourage nasal lavage until respiratory status improves
   .
   # OSA: On biPAP at home.  Will continue on high flow canula and hold
   biPAP tonight given hypoxia.
   --- Continue BiPAP PRN
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:
   -- Continue Atorvastatin
   .
   # FEN/GI:
   -- cardiac healthy diet
   -- nutrition consult
   .
   #Prophy:
   DVT - Coumadin
   Bowel regimen - senna, docusate
   pain - tylenol
   .
   #ACCESS: PIV
   # Communication:
   [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (wife) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12544**]
   [**Name (NI) 12545**] [**Name (NI) 12543**] (son) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12546**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: cardiac healthy
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2159-4-24**] 05:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Holding Coumadin (supratherapeutic)
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition: CCU
